issues.title: SNMP requires multiverse on ubuntu
issues.body: Multiverse is not guaranteed to be enabled by our cookbooks.  Simply adding it as an apt-repo resource makes apt-get complain about duplicate sources.list entries.

issues.title: Allow operations to take over service management post installation
issues.body:
The deployment of configuration and the restarting of services on large swift clusters must be carefully orchestrated and managed by a swift knowledgeable operator.

There should be a "production" flag that disables all swift-related service management in chef for those large deployments.

This includes syslog-ng as well as the general swift services, but not necessarily supplemental services like keystone, mysql, ntp.

This should be part of the "scalable swift" milestone.

Lock Berksfile to known working external deps

Mostly because of the yum 3.x upgrade that we don't yet support across

from stable branch.

Fix swift-recon-cron lock errors

Depending on timing, and if you're running the chef client install pre
or post ring creation, the swift-recon-cron job might run, fail on no
drives, die with an error and leave the lock_dir in place. On the second
run, cron gets angry and the lock_dir must be removed before this task
will ever run properly even after ring/drive setup.

Only run the cron job if some form of /etc/swift/*.ring.gz exists.

restarts on every run.

@rpedde-rcbops Looking into this as it bugs me on other Cent installs as well. And it's Friday.

This is not really ntp, but whatever the first package maybe be that gets installed via the package resource. It's Cent/yum and how they check for available vs installed versions.

TL;DR

If I just run the ntp cookbook on Centos, it's pretty fast after the initial install. When you start to add things like yum:epel from osops, and then the rcb repos, the ntp install line gets longer and longer. This is because the package resource is dumping a list of all available packages, then comparing the installed version to that list to see if there is an upgrade available. The more repos, the longer the list, the longer the first call to package is. If you add another package install in a prior recipe, that resource becomes the one that takes a long time, etc. 

There seem to be a few tickets around makecache and the yum book. Didn't dig any further.

closes #141

Align partitions on optimized boundaries

Since more and more drives are coming with 4K sectors, a 0
starting position results in unaligned drives.

We could start the partition at a 4K boundary, but that still
makes parted whine because of alignment rules having to do with
flash devices.  If we start at 1M, all drives types are properly
aligned, parted doesn't complain, and we lose a reasonably
insignificant amount of disk space.

So that's what we'll do.

issue_comments.body: retest

Yeah, I get that.  But restarting syslog shouldn't cause any problems.  Restart the collecting syslog and remote clients should reconnect and start streaming again.  Restarting local syslog should be fine -- they should queue in the kernel ring buffer and get thrown away appropriately until syslog restarts.

In no case should restarting syslog anywhere cause the proxy servers to bork.  Apparently it does, with sounds to me like a bug in something.  Don't really care where.  Just want to know if it is a bug that exhibits itself when:
1. Collecting (central) syslog server restarts, causing downstream proxy servers to choke?

or
1. Local syslog server restarts, causing proxy on the same box to choke?

My question wasn't the implementation of the thing, or directed towards maintenance procedures, it's just literally a question of which syslog server you meant.  local or central/collecting syslog server.
retest
retest
I think the easiest way might be just to drop a correct syslog-ng.conf, and don't honor the conf.d
or maybe honor the conf.d, but just whack the existing syslog-ng.conf so the base is right.  This will likely have the side effect of putting logs in the places we expect.
Will implement this way then.  When I have a first pass, I'll bounce it off you and you can check it for sanity.
